citeinfo.origin: University of South Florida College of Marine Science
citeinfo.title: Homosassa Coastal Station-Coastal Ocean Monitoring and Prediction System (COMPS)

descript.abstract: The Homosassa station is located at 28Â° 46.34' N (28.772Â° N) and 82Â° 42.43' W (82.707Â° W) on the top of USCG channel marker #26 at the entrance to Homosassa river, Citrus County, Florida. It is a 5-pile wooden structure with a 4 ft by 4 ft platform. The SW and NE sides display `26' on a triangular red day shape. The red Coast Guard navigation light is a 4-second flasher 16 ft above MHHW. O nboard instrumentation monitors Wind Speed/Direction, Relative Humidity/Air Temperature, Barometric Pressure, Precipitation, Water Level, Water Temperature and Salinity. Data is hourly transmitted via the GOES satellite for internet posting as well as radio modemed directly to the Citrus County Office of Emergency Management. Site funding is via a cooperative effort between the Citrus County Office of Emergency Management and the University of South Florida's/College of Marine Science.
descript.purpose: The University of South Florida has implemented a real-time Coastal Ocean Monitoring and Prediction System (COMPS) for West Florida. COMPS consists of an array of instrumentation, both along the coast and offshore, combined with numerical circulation models, and builds upon existing in-situ measurements and modeling programs funded by various state and federal agencies. COMPS provides additional data needed for a variety of management issues, including more accurate predictions of coastal flooding by storm surge, safety and efficiency of marine navigation, search and rescue efforts, and fisheries management. COMPS also supports basic research programs.
descript.supplinf: The University of South Florida implemented COMPS in 1997 for West Florida as a State of Florida legislative initiative. The real-time and non real-time meteorological and oceanographic data collected from coastal stations and offshore buoy stations maintained by USF along the West Florida Shelf are part of the COMPS initiative. All USF-COMPS coastal stations are equipped with Aquatrak acoustic water level measurement sensors. The coastal stations also have a variety of meteorological and oceanographic sensors: RM Young anemometers for wind speed and direction, barometric pressure sensors, air temperature and realtive humidity sensors, rain gages, water temperature and conductivity sensors, fluorometers and transmissometers. Note that not all the stations have all these sensors. They are installed on each stations based on the need. COMPS buoy-mounted meteorological sensors consist of either the Coastal Environmental Systems Weatherpak 2000 system, modified to accommodate GOES telemetry, or the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (WHOI) Improved METeorology (IMET) system, which has now evolved into the Air Sea Interaction METeorology (ASIMET) system, which is presently being manufactured by Star Engineering. The data logger and telemetry system is developed by University of South Florida Center for Ocean Technology. The Weatherpaks measure wind speed and direction, air and water temperature, relative humidity, and barometric pressure. IMET and ASIMET measures the above parameters plus incoming short and long wave radiation and precipitation. The COMPS buoys are also mounted with Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) and the MicroCAT sensors. The ADCP sensor measures the speed of the ocean current and direction of the ocean current flowing toward. COMPS is partner in the SouthEast Atlantic Coastal Ocean Observing System (SEACOOS), regional observing system to form the Coastal Component of the Integrated Ocean Observing System(IOOS). (previous geoform was 'tabular digital data')

idinfo.useconst: Following academic courtesy standards, the COMPS Co-Directors (see Originator), the University of South Florida College of Marine Science, and the Grantor (see Data Set Credit) should be fully acknowledged in any subsequent publications in which any part of these data are used. Use of the data without completely reading and understanding the metadata is not recommended. Neither the University of South Florida, the USF College of Marine Science researchers, nor the State of Florida are responsible for the misuse of data from this database (see Distribution Liability).

cntperp.cntper: Dr. Mark E. Luther or Dr. Robert H. Weisberg

cntaddr.address: 140 7th Avenue South College of Marine Science University of South Florida

idinfo.datacred: The COMPS program is supported by the State of Florida and the University of South Florida, College of Marine Science. The Anclote station is funded in part by the Emergency Management Preparedness and Assistance Trust Fund, and the Pasco County Division of Emergency Management. It is maintained by the USF College of Marine Science. Dr. Mark Luther and Dr. Bob Weisberg are the Co-directors of the COMPS Program. The COMPS field program directors, COMPS data manager, and COMPS system administrator have also contributed to the dataset.
idinfo.native: The raw and de-coded data from this station is stored in SGI/Linux and PC/Windows based computers and are presently served over the internet.

attracc.attraccr: USF COMPS Coastal Stations Weather Monitoring System Accuracy (Anclote Gulf Park Coastal Station) Wind Speed: +/- 0.3 m/sec or 3% Wind Direction: 5 - 7.8 Deg. Air Temperature: +/-0.3 deg. C Water Temperature: +/-0.2 deg. C Water Level: Calibration: Standard: +/- 0.025% Optional: +/- 0.01% Nonlinearity: +/- 0.02% Precision : +/- 0.01% Stability, : 0 Drift, 1 Year Temperature Drift: <1 ppm/deg C Conductivity: Normalized to 25 Deg. C - +/- 1% over Range 0-30 deg C Non-Normalised - 0.2% over range 0-30 deg C Barometric Pressure:+/- 0.5 hPa (0.02 in Hg) @ 20 deg. C +/- 2.0 hPa (0.06 in Hg) over temp.range Relative Humidity:3% from 10 to 90% RH at 20 deg. C 4% from 0to10 and 90to100% RH at 20 deg. C Precipitation: +/- 0.4 mm per hour

dataqual.complete: The near real-time data telemetred from the Homosassa Coastal Station data can be accessed via the website http://comps1.marine.usf.edu/hom/. The Homosassa Station website is updated every hour, and data for the past 24-hour in report form can be accessed via the website. Various Data Display (Time series and Wind Vector plots) plots (Past 24 hours and 5- Days) are also available for download from the website. The details of data format are also provided in the website. The decoded data files of the USF COMPS Anclote site can be accessed by pointing the browser to the URL:ftp://comps.marine.usf.edu/pub/hom. The data format details are also available. For further details on data availability and access, please contact COMPS Program Data Manager. The station log of maintenance, problems, and observations relevant to the Sensor systems on the stations are maintained in College of Marine Science, University of South Florida, St. Petersburg, Florida. The raw data telemetred from the station are archived at College of Marine Science, University of South Florida. The raw data will be provided based on request to the Pricipal Investigators of the USF COMPS Project.

procstep.procdesc: A brief overview of the data processing steps of USFCMS COMPS Coastal and Offshore weather monitoring data is presented here. Detailed description of the processing scripts used are available at College of Marine Science, University of South Florida. USF has two downlink systems to acquire the coastal and offshore stations data via GOES: a Digital Direct Reading Ground Station (DDRGS) and a Domestic Satellite rebroadcast receiving system (DOMSAT). We also download our data from NESDIS using Local Readout Ground Station software package obtained from NOAA, NESDIS. The hourly data streams (meteorological and water parameters) received from coastal stations consist of ten 6-minute samples. The hourly data streams (measurements of meteorological parameters) that are received from the offshore stations consist of four 15-minute and three 20-minute samples for buoys equipped with Coastal Climate WeatherPak systems and USF/ASIMET systems respectively. The ADCP (velocities, direction) consist of one sample per hour. The salinity and temperature data consist of three 20 minute samples on IMET/ASIMET type buoys and two 30 minute samples on coastal climate weatherpak buoys. Once received the data are processed using decoder scripts written in C and Perl programming languages. Observations are then served to the public via the Internet at http://comps.marine.usf.edu. These data are also available via the NDBC who have direct access for input to the National Center for Environmental Prediction for improved marine weather forecasts at http://www.ndbc.noaa.gov/Maps/Florida.shtml. The most recent observations, graphics and reports (past one and five days duration) generated from the data are available for download from the individual station web site. Development of a web based data management system is in progress.

enttyp.enttypd: The attributes in this entity describe the observations made by the instruments at the station every six minutes. Column headers (attribute labels) are inserted ahead of each six-minute data record. NOTE: A header string containing GOES transmitter information and other station information is inserted approximately hourly. This header string contains the date of observation (see Overview Description for interpretation of this header string).

overview.eaover: The individual environmental observations made at this station are described in the Detailed Description of this metadata record. Each six-minute record of observations is preceded by a row of column headers. Approximately every hour, a GOES transmission header string is inserted into the ASCII data file. This string contains the GOES transmitter message information, transmitter status, and water level benchmark information. This header string is described in the data format file (.fmt) contained in the data file directory for this station on the USF COMPS ftp site. The environmental measurements that were transmitted during that message appear below the header string. The primary and secondary water level values in the data record represent the distance from the sensor to the water surface, so a receding water level will appear as an increase in the value. To obtain the correct water level, use the computation provided in the station's format (.fmt) file with staff (benchmark) offset and sensor offset. Missing values are denoted by -99. Prior to May, 1999, column headers were not inserted in the data file; see the format file (ftp://comps.marine.usf.edu/pub/hom/hom.fmt) in the USF COMPS ftp server for an explanation of columns in the data files before May, 1999.
overview.eadetcit: See USF COMPS ftp server for format file (ftp://comps.marine.usf.edu/pub/hom/hom.fmt),See NOAA GOES transmitter web site for more information about transmitter operation (http://dcs.noaa.gov),See "Users Guide Model 4100 Series Aquatrak" for information about the operation of the water level sensor--available from http://www.cpacc.org/download/4100%20Manual%20070100.pdf,See USF COMPS ftp server for sensor heights referenced to NAVD 88: ftp://comps.marine.usf.edu/pub/comps_stn_details/usfsc_stn_sensor_hts.htm

distinfo.distliab: This server (comps.marine.usf.edu) provides real-time oceanographic data to the public; however, all data are provisional and have not been quality-controlled. While all due care is taken to provide accurate information, provisional data are subject to change or retraction after quality control and before official release. No warranty is made, express or implied, regarding the accuracy or validity of the data, or regarding the suitability of the data for any particular application. This server is not an official source for these data products. For further information please contact the distributor.
